item.title: Samuel L. Katz, a Developer of the Measles Vaccine, Dies at 94
item.description: In 1956, when he began working with a small group in a Boston laboratory, measles was a major threat. Seven years later, lifesaving immunizations began.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Tornadoes Touch Down in Northeast Texas
item.description: Tornadoes tore through parts of Texas, Arkansas and Oklahoma, damaging dozens of homes and leaving thousands of people without power, according to officials.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Storyful

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Forward/The Paris News, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Extensive damage caused by a tornado near Lamar County Road 35940, near Midcity, Texas on Friday.

item.title: In a Michigan swing county, a Republican candidate asks canvassers to focus on crime.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

media:content.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Matthew DePerno, the Republican candidate for Michigan attorney general, recited the Pledge of Allegiance at a campaign event for Tudor Dixon in Clinton Township on Friday. Ms. Dixon is trying to unseat the incumbent governor.

item.title: Catching Up With Rob Simmeljkaer, the Next Leader of the NYC Marathon
item.description: Rob Simmelkjaer was a top executive at ESPN and worked on air at NBC. As he prepares to take over New York Road Runners, he wants new races and to promote running as a tool for improving mental health.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman

media:content.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rob Simmelkjaer, the incoming chief executive of the New York Road Runners.

item.title: Is Use of the Death Penalty Ever Moral?
item.description: Readers point to flaws in the justice and mental health systems, and one calls it “barbaric.”

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Mike Stocker, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Hui Wang, whose son, Peter, was killed by Nikolas Cruz at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., after the jury rejected a death sentence for Mr. Cruz.

item.title: We Need to Be Clear About Who Pushed Us to the Breaking Point
item.description: Protecting democracy should not be a partisan issue, but it is.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: Freddy Rodríguez, 76, Artist Who Explored His Dominican Roots, Dies
item.description: His main medium was paint, but his most viewed work may have been the outdoor memorial in Queens to Flight 587.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: This Perfect Mother-Daughter Read Holds a Powerful Lesson for Fighting Antisemitism
item.description: It takes the bravery of ‘ordinary’ people.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

media:content.media:credit: Clarion Books

item.title: How the Price of Gas Became America’s Most Important Political Issue
item.description: President Biden has seen his party’s political fortunes driven by the ups and downs of energy prices since the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Meg Jacobs
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

media:content.media:credit: Sebastian Siadecki

item.title: I Write About Post-Roe America Every Day. It’s Worse Than You Think.
item.description: Vote because abortion matters.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Valenti

item.title: The Unruly Heirs of Sarah Palin
item.description: Even if Palin loses her House race next week, a new generation of conservative women stand poised to carry her complex legacy forward.
item.dc:creator: Rosie Gray

media:content.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times

item.title: John Hancock, Samuel Adams, Soul of America
item.description: We have landed at the very intersection where the founders parted ways. Very little has changed.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Schiff

media:content.media:credit: Library of Congress
media:content.media:description: Portraits of John Hancock, left, and Samuel Adams by John Singleton Copley.

item.title: Far Right’s Rise in Israel Driven by Anxiety and Fear
item.description: To win election, Benjamin Netanyahu and his far-right allies harnessed perceived threats to Israel’s Jewish identity after ethnic unrest last year and the subsequent inclusion of Arab lawmakers in the government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley

media:content.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Supporters of Benjamin Netanyahu last month during a Likud party rally in Sderot, Israel. A far-right alliance, Religious Zionism, has given back to Mr. Netanyahu his parliamentary majority.

item.title: Fetterman Makes Reference to a Steelers Legend in Resurfaced Ad
item.description: Puzzled responses on Twitter to an homage to “Mean” Joe Greene offered Fetterman supporters a chance to mock Dr. Mehmet Oz, his Republican opponent in the Pennsylvania Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

media:content.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: LaRita Wilson, 65, next to John Fetterman’s merchandise truck outside a senior center in Upper Darby, Pa., on Friday.

item.title: Astronomers Find a Black Hole in Our Cosmic Back Yard
item.description: Just 1,600 light-years away, the black hole is the closest known to Earth. The good news: It’s dormant, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)

media:content.media:credit: International Gemini Observatory/NOIRLab/NSF/AURA
media:content.media:description: An artist’s impression of the black hole and its companion star, a mere 1,600 light-years away from Earth.

item.title: Ukraine says Russia is blowing up civilian ships in Kherson to stop the military from using them.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

media:content.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A woman who fled Russian-occupied territory near Kherson embraces a soldier at a Ukrainian checkpoint near Zaporizhzia on Wednesday.

item.title: Berkshire Hathaway Reports Third-Quarter Loss
item.description: The company’s huge investment portfolio lost money, while its insurance arm felt the effects of Hurricane Ian and inflation-driven rises in property and damage claims.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

media:content.media:credit: Nati Harnik/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Warren Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, earlier this year. The company’s third-quarter earnings highlighted how much it is a microcosm of the American economy.

item.title: Here’s what’s happening on the campaign trail.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Democrats Ushered In the Los Angeles Sheriff. Now Many Want Him Gone.
item.description: Alex Villanueva’s combative approach has antagonized many officials and spurred an extraordinary ballot measure that would allow county leaders to oust him.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll and Jill Cowan

media:content.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sheriff Alex Villanueva campaigning with volunteers door-to-door in Carson, Calif., last month in his bid for re-election.

item.title: A divided household in one of the most divided districts in America.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina

media:content.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Carolyn Broe, a Republican, lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., with her husband, a Libertarian, and their two adult children, who are to the left of the Democratic Party.

item.title: How diverse are the candidates in this election? Take a look at the numbers.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor and Eleanor Lutz

item.title: $1.6 Billion Powerball Jackpot Sets Off Ticket-Buying Frenzy
item.description: The odds of getting the winning numbers are 1 in 292.2 million, but that did not dash the hopes of players ahead of the drawing on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Johnny Diaz

media:content.media:credit: Julio Cortez/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The estimated $1.6 billion Powerball jackpot is the largest in U.S. history.

item.title: The Marjorie Taylor Greene-ing of America
item.description: Many flew over the Capitol cuckoo’s nest.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

media:content.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: They Are Betting $100 Million on Pluralism. Will It Work?
item.description: A group of donors is fighting polarization by funding face-to-face interactions among Americans across political, racial and religious divides.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

media:content.media:credit: Cristina Spanò

item.title: Iran’s foreign minister acknowledges that drones were sent to Russia, but says it happened before the war.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was struck by a Russian drone attack in October.

item.title: North Korea Launches More Missiles
item.description: Tensions further escalated on the divided peninsula, with Washington deploying supersonic bombers for the first time in years as part of a military exercise.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

media:content.media:credit: South Korean Defense Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Washington and Seoul participating in a joint military exercise over South Korea on Saturday in a photograph provided by the South Korean Defense Ministry.

item.title: What Will the Midterms Mean for Big Business?
item.description: The G.O.P. and corporate America, longtime allies, are showing signs of a breakup — which recent polls suggest will likely play out with a Republican House.
item.dc:creator: Joe Nocera

media:content.media:credit: Angelica Alzona

item.title: Out Loud, Pumped Up and Bossed Around by the French
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Medicare Advantage or Just Medicare?
item.description: It’s annual enrollment season once again. Here’s a look at the pros and cons of the two approaches to health insurance.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

media:content.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The proportion of eligible Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare Advantage plans will exceed 50 percent next year, experts estimate.

item.title: ‘The Run-Up’ Podcast’s Guide to the Midterm Elections
item.description: A guide to the biggest questions heading into Election Day.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team

item.title: Ukrainian regions make contingency plans in case they fully lose electricity.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Water supplies in the basement of a school that has been prepared as a gathering point in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Time Warp
item.description: How readers are adjusting to the end of daylight saving time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Fastest Woman in This Year’s New York City Marathon Is Israeli
item.description: “You come to challenge yourself in New York City,” Lonah Chemtai Salpeter said. Her path to representing Israel was a challenge in itself.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg

media:content.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Lonah Chemtai Salpeter trained this week for the New York City Marathon.

item.title: Alleviating Canada’s Acute Shortage of Family Doctors
item.description: British Columbia announced a plan this week that will boost physicians’ incomes, but more changes may be necessary to increase nationwide access to family physicians.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: About 11 percent of Nova Scotians are without a family doctor.

item.title: Hosting Climate Summit Is Both Opportunity and Risk for Egypt
item.description: The COP27 meeting next week allows a debt-wracked African country to champion climate needs of poorer nations. But it also puts Egypt under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

media:content.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The idyllic Red Sea resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh is set to host the 27th annual United Nations-sponsored climate summit, known as COP27.

item.title: These Men Fled War in Syria to Ukraine. Now They’ve Fled Again.
item.description: Two men displaced from Syria as civil war gripped their country spent a decade living in limbo in Ukraine. But when war came to them again, they were forced to leave, eventually making their way to London.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Muhsen Hamed, left, and Abdul Safwa, two Syrians who fled Ukraine at the start of the war there. Now in London, they face a complicated path toward rebuilding their lives.

item.title: Satellite images show that a train crossed into Russia from North Korea, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

media:content.media:credit: Kyodo News Stills, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Korea-Russia Friendship Bridge seen from Khasan, Russia, in 2011.

item.title: Itaewon Goes Quiet After Deadly Crowd Crush in Seoul, South Korea
item.description: Itaewon was popular for its diversity and nightlife. A week after a disaster killed more than 150 young people there, the neighborhood is a monument of grief.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee

item.title: What Can US Democracy Learn From Brazil?
item.description: Both nations had presidents who attacked their elections. But their responses — and the aftermaths — were much different.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro blockaded a main road in São Paulo on Tuesday, one of many such protests around Brazil after he lost the election to Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.

item.title: Republican Gains in Congress Would Pressure Biden on Ukraine and Iran
item.description: Officials in the Biden administration expect plenty of complications, including summons to hearings over the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

media:content.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy said last month that a Republican-led House would be unwilling to approve “blank check” assistance for Ukraine.

item.title: Elecciones EE. UU.: mitos sobre la votación de medio término
item.description: Estas son algunas de las principales falsedades y rumores que se han difundido en las redes sociales de cara al Día de las Elecciones.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang

media:content.media:credit: Rebecca Noble para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: La desinformación y los rumores sobre el voto se han ido acumulando en las redes sociales, incluso sobre las urnas para depositar las boletas por adelantado y el voto por correo.

item.title: How an Astrophysicist Spends Her Sundays
item.description: Jackie Faherty is a people person, but the sky is a “familiar and safe friend,” too.
item.dc:creator: Alix Strauss

media:content.media:credit: Adam DelGiudice for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jackie Faherty, right, at Tap a Keg, one of her regular haunts, with her friend, Carlos Zarzuela.

item.title: Questions for Kathy Hochul and Lee Zeldin
item.description: For the first time in decades, the race for governor in New York is competitive. Here’s what you need to know.

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times, Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul, left, and Representative Lee Zeldin. The race for governor of New York has tightened in recent weeks.

item.title: Trump, Biden and Obama Will Campaign in Pennsylvania in Midterm Finale
item.description: As the midterms come to a close, the establishment politics of the two most recent Democratic presidents will meet the disruptive force of the last Republican one, with control of Congress at stake.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Michael C. Bender

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump will rally Republicans on Saturday in southwest Pennsylvania, while President Biden and former President Barack Obama will speak to Democrats in Philadelphia.

item.title: 20 Years of Roman and Williams Design: Hotels, Restaurants, Guild
item.description: Ask the founders of Roman and Williams, who for two decades have designed homes, hotels, restaurants, clubs, galleries, stores, furniture — even birdhouses — bathed in a luxe patina.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Reid
item.category: Roman and Williams Buildings and Interiors

media:content.media:credit: Landon Speers for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Roman and Williams founders Stephen Alesch and Robin Standefer pivoted to interior design after working on films. “The stars and producers on these movie sets said, ‘Why don’t our houses look as good as the movie sets?’” she said.

item.title: It Looks Like a Shell, but an Octopus and 40,000 Eggs Live Inside
item.description: Scientists are studying how the argonaut octopus evolved the ability to produce a floating shell-like structure to care for its offspring.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Quaglia

item.title: Ahead of the Midterms, Family Ties Are Strained by Political Divisions
item.description: For Carolyn Broe and her family, the 2022 midterms have unfolded the way they have for countless others: with great bitterness and turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina

media:content.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Carolyn Broe, a Republican, lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., with her husband, a Libertarian, and their two adult children, who are to the left of the Democratic Party.

item.title: Pranks, Parties and Politics: Ron DeSantis’s Year as a Schoolteacher
item.description: At a private school 20 years ago, the future Florida governor was a popular history teacher and coach. But some students were taken aback by his comments on the Civil War and abortion.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ron DeSantis taught at Darlington School, a private boarding school in Rome, Ga., in the 2001-02 school year, after graduating from Yale University and just before attending Harvard Law School.

item.title: For These New York Farmers, Harvest Time Means High Times
item.description: In fields from Sag Harbor to Ithaca, a new crop ripened this fall: cannabis plants grown for recreational marijuana.
item.dc:creator: John Ortved and Paul Barbera

media:content.media:credit: Paul Barbera for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In the 1930s, the growing of cannabis was all but banned across the United States.
